results.title: Virginia Woolf's criticism of the novel 'Life escapes'
results.creator_credit: Richard Callanan, BBC-TV and Open University
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The 19th Century Novel”.
Following a dramatised scene from Virginia Woolf’s novel “Life Escapes”, Professor Arnold Kettle argues that Virginia Woolf was not just telling a story but recreating an era of reality and this leads her to break with the traditional form of the novel in a way which emphasises the moment-to-moment impressions of life.

results.title: Violin lesson. No. 1
results.brief_description: Fantasy on the theme practice makes perfect. A cut paper and cloth animation for children in which we see all that can be done to convince a little boy to take his violin lessons. No dialogue.

results.title: Violent killer = Violence at noon = Hakuchu no torima
results.brief_description: The disturbing story of a brutal, serial sex murderer, his protective wife and a woman he has previously raped. The two women shield the criminal from the police, each feeling a perverse sense of loyalty to him, one due to marriage, the other because he once saved her life. Oshima presents a taut, intelligent, and visually spellbinding portrait of repression, victimisation, and guilt, using high contrast, frequent jump cuts, isolated framing, changing character perspective, and elliptical narrative to reflect the mental polarity and deviant behavior of an amoral predator. Cast includes Saeda Kawaguchi, Akiko Koyama, Kei Sato, Mutsuhiro Toura, Fumio Watanabe. In Japanese with English subtitles.

results.title: Vinyl chloride production
results.creator_credit: Barrie Whatley, BBC-TV and Open University
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Principles of Chemical Processes”
The plant used at Baglan Bay to convert ethylene and chlorine to vinyl chloride involves three main processes. The first part examines the materials flow and plant operations in each of these processes, and how the three processes are integrated to produce a continuous process. The remainder is concerned with a theoretical analysis of the equipment and operating conditions

results.title: Vintage: A History of Wine. Eps. 3 & 4
results.creator_credit: Christopher Ralling, Michael Gill, Channel 4, Malone Gill Productions and WGBH (Boston)
results.brief_description: The empire of the vine tells how cultivation of the vine brought civilisation to the Mediterranean, through the Greeks and Romans who spread its cultivation from the area around Pompeii, to Tuscany and into France via the Rhone valley. “Northern limits” looks at the history of German vineyards along the Moselle and Rhine rivers. Initiated by the Romans at Trier, continued by Charlemagne and the Cistercian monks in the middle ages, experiments with new wines continue to this day in this apparently inhospitable climate.

results.title: Vintage: A History of Wine. Eps. 1 & 2
results.creator_credit: Christopher Ralling, Michael Gill, Channel 4, Malone Gill Productions and WGBH (Boston)
results.brief_description: The first two episodes of a thirteen part survey by Hugh Johnson of the history of wine. “First pressing” looks at the origins of winemaking in the Caucusus mountains of Georgia and its enjoyment in ancient middle eastern cultures until the prohibition enforced by Islam. “Drinking the god” looks at the role wine has played in religious ceremonies from pagan sacrifices, Dionysian orgies and Jewish ritual to the Christian mass. The programs look at how Georgia and the Middle East use and produce wine today.

results.title: Vindhya Pradesh
results.creator_credit: Mushir Ahmad, M. Bhavnani and Films Division, Government of India
results.brief_description: The State of Vindhya Pradesh includes 26 of the 36 former principalities of Central India. This film deals with the development of the State and the people who depend on the diamond and limestone mines for their living. Also presents sidelights of its great historical past.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Mushir Ahmad, M. Bhavnani and Films Division, Government of India

results.title: Village of the rain forest, Nigeria
results.creator_credit: Juniper Films and Tristram Wilson Productions
results.brief_description:
We see through the eyes of children one village in this land of eighty million, touched by the strong tide of change. The village stands for tradition while the cities represents modernity. The wealth which has transformed the cities must now be harnessed to the betterment of rural life, to give balance and sustenance to all Nigerians.
Suitable for upper primary and lower secondary levels.
